 Firstly, how do you obtain scientific evidence from inside a nation that threw out the UN weapons inspectors? The purpose of sending weapons inspectors was to look for evidence of Iraq re-initiating its WMD programs. But as they were thrown out of the country, the world was left in the dark as to whether anything was going on. Should the Coalition have waited in the hope that Hussein would let in the inspectors by the goodness of his heart? I realise that he did let the weapons inspectors search the country later on, but only after military build-up on Iraq's borders, and also years after the inspectors requested to go back in. It wouldn't be that absurd to think that he hid is weapons and programs in the time where there was no UN presence.
 
 To lend from a previous post (notice who this is said by also):
 
 "What is at stake is how to answer the potential threat Iraq represents with the risk of proliferation of WMD. Baghdad's regime did use such weapons in the past. Today, a number of evidences may lead to think that, over the past four years, in the absence of international inspectors, this country has continued armament programs." -- Jacques Chirac, October 16, 2002 
 
 "I am absolutely convinced that there are weapons...I saw evidence back in 1998 when we would see the inspectors being barred from gaining entry into a warehouse for three hours with trucks rolling up and then moving those trucks out." -- Clinton's Secretary of Defense William Cohen in April of 2003 
 
 Plus, there were witnesses consulted, the most notable being Chalabi. Though, it turns out that he was most likely divulging false information about the situation. And from the recent articles dmann has posted, you'd wonder why any administration would belive what he had to say without sufficient evidence to support his intel.
 
 We can go around in cirlces asking who was right, was the intel correct, who is to blame? But because the majority of the information needed to assess the situation is confidential, the general public (ie. us) is not privvy to it.
 
 As for the second part of the post, a terrorist is "one who uses or favors terrorising methods of resisting a government, or of governing." Are you up to date with the recent history of Iraq?
